mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (PDF-967 KB)</span></a></div></div></div></div> <p><strong>Between</strong> the 2017 open enrollment period (OEP) and the 2018 OEP, McKinsey’s Center for U.S. Health System Reform conducted its fourth annual survey of consumers eligible (under the Affordable Care Act) for coverage in the individual exchange market.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c6f64d3f-b09b-4273-a00a-c06f75f05dbb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c6f64d3f-b09b-4273-a00a-c06f75f05dbb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">This survey included both individually insured and uninsured respondents to understand the attitudes and purchasing behaviors of consumers who are eligible for coverage in the individual exchange market. Those enrolled in employer-sponsored insurance, Medicare, or Medicaid, as well as those uninsured who are Medicaid-eligible, were excluded from the survey population. See additional details on the survey design and respondents in the appendix.</span></span></span></a></span> Although some changes have been made to the market since the survey was fielded—most notably, removal of the individual mandate penalty and authorization of the use of short-term and association health plans—the findings have important implications for payers, providers, government leaders, and other healthcare stakeholders. These findings can help inform 2018 retention efforts, future product designs, and outreach campaigns to enroll the uninsured.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="03972fb3-fcc2-4d9a-81f4-4251655dab37"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="03972fb3-fcc2-4d9a-81f4-4251655dab37" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey is a non-partisan firm and has a long-standing policy of neither commenting on nor advocating for specific government policies. We do not provide policy advice, and the findings in this paper should not be taken as such.</span></span></span></a></span> Among the most important insights:</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor-signup mck-o-sm-left-span mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-signup"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-7 DisruptorSignUp_mck-c-disruptor-signup__heading__JR4i0"><div>Stay current on your favorite topics</div></h2></div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--align-left"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/user-registration/register-mvc" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--primary___Ed-lT_990311c mdc-c-button--size-large___jwpUy_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Subscribe</span></a></div></div>

<ul>
	<li><strong>More stable consumer behaviors.</strong> While the regulatory and industry views of the market for individual insurance continue to change, consumer behavior has become more consistent over time.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bb937d25-f94a-4edd-95a3-d88686407078"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bb937d25-f94a-4edd-95a3-d88686407078" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">This finding is consistent with reports that despite significant changes to the 2018 OEP, 11.8 million people enrolled for coverage—only a 3.7% drop from last year’s total enrollment. (National Academy for State Health Policy. Individual market enrollment remains stable in the face of national uncertainty. February 8, 2018.)</span></span></span></a></span> Carrier loyalty has increased, for example. Most respondents with healthcare coverage said that they plan to stay insured, even if changes to the market (e.g., removal of individual mandate penalty) were made.</li>
	<li><strong>Encouraging uninsured enrollment.</strong> Getting a significant number of consumers who remain uninsured to purchase coverage appears to be possible, not only through the use of “traditional” levers (e.g., more affordable products, greater awareness of subsidies) but also through the addition of downside risk<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6cca4189-22f8-48a0-b573-1974ebd52074"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6cca4189-22f8-48a0-b573-1974ebd52074" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">In the absence of the individual mandate penalty, additional downside risk mechanisms could include surcharges (when purchasing coverage) for not having been insured for a period of time or the possibility of being denied future coverage.</span></span></span></a></span> for not purchasing. In our survey, downside risk appeared to be approximately twice as effective at encouraging uninsured enrollment as was offering catastrophic plans with significantly lower premiums.</li>
	<li><strong>Limited perception of premium increases.</strong> Although gross premiums in the individual exchange market rose 25% in 2017, the impact on net premiums was less significant.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9f2b6ef3-904e-4e56-bd78-36fde5f0ebb1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9f2b6ef3-904e-4e56-bd78-36fde5f0ebb1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The McKinsey Center for U.S. Health System Reform has calculated that the changes to net premium varied in 2017 from a decrease of as much as 13% to an increase of as much as 21%, depending on income level and resulting subsidy eligibility.</span></span></span></a></span> Consistent with this, most of the survey respondents reported having had either no or a relatively modest increase in premiums (most likely because, in many cases, subsidies had insulated them from price increases). Nevertheless, many of the respondents who had purchased health insurance indicated that they were facing challenges because of high costs, and some had stopped paying premiums during the year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="14bf3fe2-152d-4e60-8942-7a1b0321e4c7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="14bf3fe2-152d-4e60-8942-7a1b0321e4c7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">While some of those who stopped paying premiums may have gained other forms of coverage, the majority remained in the individual exchanged market, as we discuss later in the article.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
	<li><strong>Consumer trade-offs to reduce costs.</strong> Many respondents to our 2017 survey, like those in previous years, said they would like to better manage their healthcare costs, including premiums and out-of-pocket spending, and they are willing to take actions to do so. However, familiarity with the options that could help them manage costs (e.g., healthcare savings accounts [HSAs]) remains low.</li>
</ul>

<p>These findings are discussed below. More details about the survey can be found in the appendix below.</p>

<h2>More stable consumer behavior</h2>

<p>Although the regulatory and industry views of the market for individual insurance may remain in flux, consumer understanding and behavior appears to be more stable. For example, awareness of subsidies rose steeply between 2015 and 2016 but has remained steady in subsequent years (Exhibit 1). Awareness of the penalty for not having coverage followed a similar pattern.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Respondents' awareness of ACA subsidies has stabilized" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>Similarly, the percentage of respondents who ranked lowest-cost premium as the most important purchasing factor dropped significantly between 2014 and 2016, but it has stabilized in the 23% to 24% range since then (Exhibit 2).</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The importance of lowest premium in plan selection has declined" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p>Stability in consumers’ behavior is also reflected in their relatively high loyalty to current carriers. Overall, 82% of the respondents to the 2017 survey had renewed with the same insurer they had in 2016. Whether the same plan was available had a significant impact on renewal rates, though. If it was, carrier loyalty rose to 94%, but if it was not, loyalty dropped to 44% (Exhibit 3).</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Carrier loyalty drops wen consumers are not offered the same plan" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p>Further, when we tested consumers’ reactions to possible removal of the individual mandate, 90% of individually insured respondents say they would continue to purchase health insurance (unless premiums became unaffordable).</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/healthcare/how-we-help-clients">Healthcare Systems & Services Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Visit our Payor Strategy page</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>

<h2>Encouraging uninsured enrollment</h2>

<p>Decreasing the size of the uninsured population remains an important aspiration for the individual exchange market. Our survey produced two important findings in this regard. First, the longer a consumer has been uninsured, the less likely he or she is to obtain coverage. For example, 65% of the respondents who had been uninsured for one year or less said they had shopped for a plan in 2017. In contrast, only 37% of those who had been uninsured for three years or more reported having done the same. Second, getting a significant number of uninsured individuals to purchase insurance appears to be possible. However, a marked change in incentives—specifically, the addition of downside risk for not having coverage—may be required.</p>

<p>The individual mandate penalty, which was eliminated in the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017, is one type of downside risk, but other options have been considered. In our survey, we explored customer reactions to several of these options (in all cases, we asked respondents to assume that the individual mandate penalty had been removed). Two types of downside risk produced significant increases in the percentage of uninsured individuals who said they would purchase insurance (Exhibit 4):<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e85db2c3-00ac-4252-80eb-34b65126cbda"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e85db2c3-00ac-4252-80eb-34b65126cbda" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The approaches to downside risk tested in the survey were based on various Republican and Democratic proposals from early 2017; additional details are included in the appendix.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The uninsured react differently to different scenarios" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Waiting period and surcharge.</strong> The first scenario focused on what uninsured respondents would do if not having insurance for 63 or more days would result in them having to wait until the next calendar year to regain coverage and then having to pay a 30% surcharge every month of the first year for the new plan.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6195e624-dc32-442e-9267-dc6456571d07"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6195e624-dc32-442e-9267-dc6456571d07" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">This approach was based on a proposal that had been included in the American Health Care Act of 2017 (H.R. 1628). That Act was passed by the House of Representatives but not by the Senate.</span></span></span></a></span> Sixty-seven percent of the uninsured said that they would enroll in a plan in this scenario. This result is consistent with effects we have observed in the Medicare Part D market, where consumers’ premiums can increase based on how long they have gone without “creditable” prescription drug coverage.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="591146e1-3b5e-4c55-afb5-6ceefb79c444"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="591146e1-3b5e-4c55-afb5-6ceefb79c444" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Medicare Part D enrollees that have not had “creditable prescription drug coverage” for a continuous period of 63 days or more will pay a penalty amount in addition to base-level premiums that equals 1% of the national base beneficiary premium.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
	<li><strong>Coverage denial or premium increases.</strong> The second scenario focused on what uninsured respondents would do if a coverage gap of 63 days or more gave health insurers the right to deny them coverage if they developed a new medical condition or take that condition into account when pricing the plan.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1121a974-5be7-4c31-a6ee-ca8753830471"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1121a974-5be7-4c31-a6ee-ca8753830471" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">This scenario was based on actions permissible to payers prior to passage of the Affordable Care Act.</span></span></span></a></span> In this scenario, 71% of the uninsured said they would obtain coverage. This result is consistent with what we have observed in the disability and life insurance markets, where purchasers have a financial incentive to sign up for coverage before they develop an adverse condition.</li>
</ul>

<p>In contrast, there is some evidence that, in isolation, penalties are not understood by respondents or causing them to change their behavior. For example, about two-thirds of the uninsured respondents indicated that they were not aware of the individual mandate penalty. Among the uninsured who were aware of it, less than half said they had paid a penalty for not having insurance in 2016.</p>

<p>More details about the uninsured survey respondents can be found in the sidebar below.</p>

<h2>Limited perception of premium increases</h2>

<p>Although gross premiums in the individual exchange market rose by an average of 25% in 2017,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e8366369-2ec2-4427-9966-09ebb8d8a643"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e8366369-2ec2-4427-9966-09ebb8d8a643" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">ASPE Research Brief. Health plan choice and premiums in the 2018 federal health insurance exchange. October 30, 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> our survey indicates that most purchasers were insulated from the increasing costs or were unaware of the increase in premiums they experienced.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f606f282-748a-455d-8e9b-c9c8c3ca8e00"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f606f282-748a-455d-8e9b-c9c8c3ca8e00" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Center for U.S. Health System Reform. Insights into the 2018 individual exchange market. November 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> Among the respondents who had health insurance coverage, 66% reported that their premiums had decreased, stayed the same, or increased by no more than 10% from 2016 to 2017. These results can likely be attributed, in part, to the subsidies many purchasers received.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1a333b53-dfa7-4eaf-90ed-78c91c9d1712"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1a333b53-dfa7-4eaf-90ed-78c91c9d1712" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The McKinsey Center for U.S. Health System Reform has calculated that the changes to net premium varied in 2017 from a decrease of as much as 13% to an increase of as much as 21%, depending on income level and resulting subsidy eligibility.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Nevertheless, many of the purchasers indicated that they were facing challenges because of high costs. For example, 17% of the insured respondents reported that they had stopped paying their premiums in 2017—yet 84% of this group repurchased an exchange plan in 2017 (Exhibit 5). In fact, 29% of these respondents repurchased the same plan they had stopped paying for in 2016. These findings are consistent with the results of a previous surveys, which found that one in five ACA-insured respondents had stopped paying their premiums in 2015—87% of whom then repurchased an exchange plan in 2016.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Many payment stoppers repurchase coverage the following year" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p>Similarly, about 21% of the 2017 respondents reported having overdue medical bills. The median amount owed was roughly $1,400. And, 34% of the respondents said they had tried to negotiate down a medical bill with a hospital or doctor.</p>

data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Who are the uninsured?</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Encouraging more uninsured individuals to obtain health insurance coverage is an important goal. Despite considerable efforts to incentivize consumers to purchase health insurance (through greater awareness of subsidies, the application of penalties, and other approaches), 12.2% of US adults remain uninsured.<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote16" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="0730e09f-01f0-4d8a-b730-9cb1cb388298" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">16</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span id="footnote16" class="tooltip"><span class="footnote-content">
<span class="footnote-number">16.</span>
<span class="footnote-text" id="0730e09f-01f0-4d8a-b730-9cb1cb388298"><span></span>Auter Z. U.S. uninsured rate steady at 12.2% in fourth quarter of 2017. Gallup.com. January 16, 2018.</span>
<span class="clear"></span></span>
<span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span>
 Uninsured consumers tend to be different from individuals who choose to purchase health insurance in many ways, including their age, health, employment status, attitudes, and length of being uninsured.</p>

<h3>Age and health</h3>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 7</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit7.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Uninsured respondents are disproportionately younger and have fewer chronic conditions" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit7.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<h3>Employment status</h3>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 8</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit8.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Uninsured respondents were more likely to be unemployed" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit8.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<h3>Attitudes</h3>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 9</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit9_2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The uninsured were more cost sensitive than the insured and placed less importance on insurance coverage" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit9_2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<h3>Length of being insured</h3>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 10</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit10.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="A majority of the uninsured have been uninsured since 2015" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit10.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>Our survey results show that many consumers would like to better manage their healthcare costs, including premiums and out-of-pocket payments, and are willing to take actions to do so. For example, 35% of the uninsured respondents said that, to reduce their costs, they had avoided visiting a doctor for a minor illness in the past 12 months. Similarly, 20% of the uninsured respondents reported having asked for generic alternatives when prescribed medication, and 13% had postponed elective treatments. Individually insured patients said they would take similar actions in the future if they did not have coverage.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="67f88e9f-43ff-4ee9-a7bf-fc95907b1d66"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="67f88e9f-43ff-4ee9-a7bf-fc95907b1d66" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">When the individually insured respondents were asked about the actions they would take to reduce medical costs if they did not have insurance, 42% said they would avoid visiting a doctor for a minor illness, 42% said they would ask for generic alternatives when prescribed medication, and 25% said they would postpone elective treatments.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>In addition, most respondents said they were willing to make changes to their plans to reduce costs. When the respondents were asked to trade off between benefits and premium, the benefits chosen for removal most often were maternity/newborn care, mental health coverage, and preferred branded drugs. (Interestingly, men and women were equally likely to say they would forfeit maternity/newborn care, but few young respondents of either sex were willing to make this trade-off.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7b6b96fb-1c17-4cc2-b03f-1e933f1c337d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7b6b96fb-1c17-4cc2-b03f-1e933f1c337d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">58% of men and 58% women said that they would be willing to remove this benefit to reduce premiums.</span></span></span></a></span>) The top three benefits respondents said they wanted to keep were hospitalization, emergency room services, and urgent care. Thus, it appears that there is an opportunity to increase consumer engagement through product design.</p>

<p>Health savings accounts (HSAs) are another option consumers could potentially use to help lower their out-of-pocket medical expenses (e.g., deductibles, coinsurance, co-payments). In our survey, however, 79% of the respondents said they had never had an HSA, and roughly half the respondents did not know which healthcare expenses could be paid for with an HSA. Furthermore, when low-income respondents were asked what they would do if, instead of cost-sharing reductions, they received an equivalent amount as an HSA deposit, one in five said they would drop their existing insurance coverage (Exhibit 6).</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 6</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Respondents chose different strategies when asked what they would do if they received and HSA deposit rather than a CSR subsidy" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/2017%20individual%20exchange%20market%20consumer%20research%20findings/svg_openenroll_exhibit6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<hr>

<p>Our survey findings provide strong indications that consumer understanding and behavior in the individual exchange market is stabilizing. Nevertheless, stakeholders across the healthcare industry have opportunities to encourage the uninsured to purchase coverage and to empower consumers to make the trade-offs that could potentially help them address concerns about rising healthcare costs.</p>

data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Appendix</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><h3>McKinsey ACA market survey</h3>

<p>Through the McKinsey Center for U.S. Health System Reform, we regularly survey a national sample of QHP-eligible uninsured and individually insured consumers (excluding those eligible for Medicaid and Medicare). This research is independently funded by McKinsey & Company without contribution from any third party. The objective is to understand the actions, shopping, and purchasing behavior of consumers who are eligible to purchase individual coverage on the individual market exchanges or elsewhere. These surveys therefore provide snapshots of enrollment over time.</p>

<p>To date, we have completed nine rounds of surveys:</p>

<ul>
	<li>November 25 to December 6, 2013: sample size of 1,846</li>
	<li>December 16 to December 20, 2013: sample size of 1,677</li>
	<li>January 6 to January 10, 2014: sample size of 1,040</li>
	<li>February 4 to February 13, 2014: sample size of 2,096</li>
	<li>April 7 to April 16, 2014: sample size of 2,874</li>
	<li>November 6 to November 10, 2014: sample size of 2,000</li>
	<li>February 21 to February 24, 2015: sample size of 3,007</li>
	<li>February 2 to February 18, 2016: sample size of 2,763</li>
	<li>September 21 to October 18, 2017: sample size 2,993</li>
</ul>

<p>Each survey was designed and analyzed by McKinsey teams. Each survey was administered online in English by a third-party vendor. For the 2017 survey, we used the following characteristics to focus on the consumer segments eligible to purchase individual coverage on the exchanges or elsewhere:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Ages 18 to 64</li>
	<li>Income above 100% federal poverty level (FPL) in Medicaid non-expansion states and above 138% FPL in Medicaid expansion states</li>
	<li>Inclusive of both insured and uninsured individuals for 2017, regardless of coverage in 2016</li>
	<li>Primary decision-maker, equally involved in making decisions, or contributes to health insurance decisions for their household</li>
</ul>

<p>A portion of the content for this year’s survey, including various proposals that were tested, was intended to be generally consistent with formal and informal proposals from Democratic and Republican leadership that had emerged in the first half of 2017.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

the 2017 open enrollment period (OEP) and the 2018 OEP, McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Center for U.S. Health System Reform conducted its fourth annual survey of consumers eligible (under the Affordable Care Act) for coverage in the individual exchange market.[[footnote 1]] Although some changes have been made to the market since the survey was fielded\u0026mdash;most notably, removal of the individual mandate penalty and authorization of the use of short-term and association health plans\u0026mdash;the findings have important implications for payers, providers, government leaders, and other healthcare stakeholders. These findings can help inform 2018 retention efforts, future product designs, and outreach campaigns to enroll the uninsured.[[footnote 2]] Among the most important insights:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[disruptorsignup left]]\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMore stable consumer behaviors.\u003c/strong\u003e While the regulatory and industry views of the market for individual insurance continue to change, consumer behavior has become more consistent over time.[[footnote 3]] Carrier loyalty has increased, for example. Most respondents with healthcare coverage said that they plan to stay insured, even if changes to the market (e.g., removal of individual mandate penalty) were made.\u003c/li\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEncouraging uninsured enrollment.\u003c/strong\u003e Getting a significant number of consumers who remain uninsured to purchase coverage appears to be possible, not only through the use of \u0026ldquo;traditional\u0026rdquo; levers (e.g., more affordable products, greater awareness of subsidies) but also through the addition of downside risk[[footnote 4]] for not purchasing. In our survey, downside risk appeared to be approximately twice as effective at encouraging uninsured enrollment as was offering catastrophic plans with significantly lower premiums.\u003c/li\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLimited perception of premium increases.\u003c/strong\u003e Although gross premiums in the individual exchange market rose 25% in 2017, the impact on net premiums was less significant.[[footnote 5]] Consistent with this, most of the survey respondents reported having had either no or a relatively modest increase in premiums (most likely because, in many cases, subsidies had insulated them from price increases). Nevertheless, many of the respondents who had purchased health insurance indicated that they were facing challenges because of high costs, and some had stopped paying premiums during the year.[[footnote 6]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eConsumer trade-offs to reduce costs.\u003c/strong\u003e Many respondents to our 2017 survey, like those in previous years, said they would like to better manage their healthcare costs, including premiums and out-of-pocket spending, and they are willing to take actions to do so. However, familiarity with the options that could help them manage costs (e.g., healthcare savings accounts [HSAs]) remains low.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThese findings are discussed below. More details about the survey can be found in the appendix below.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eMore stable consumer behavior\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough the regulatory and industry views of the market for individual insurance may remain in flux, consumer understanding and behavior appears to be more stable. For example, awareness of subsidies rose steeply between 2015 and 2016 but has remained steady in subsequent years (Exhibit 1). Awareness of the penalty for not having coverage followed a similar pattern.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eSimilarly, the percentage of respondents who ranked lowest-cost premium as the most important purchasing factor dropped significantly between 2014 and 2016, but it has stabilized in the 23% to 24% range since then (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 2]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eStability in consumers\u0026rsquo; behavior is also reflected in their relatively high loyalty to current carriers. Overall, 82% of the respondents to the 2017 survey had renewed with the same insurer they had in 2016. Whether the same plan was available had a significant impact on renewal rates, though. If it was, carrier loyalty rose to 94%, but if it was not, loyalty dropped to 44% (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 3]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eFurther, when we tested consumers\u0026rsquo; reactions to possible removal of the individual mandate, 90% of individually insured respondents say they would continue to purchase health insurance (unless premiums became unaffordable).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[disruptor1up learnmore]]\n\n\u003ch2\u003eEncouraging uninsured enrollment\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eDecreasing the size of the uninsured population remains an important aspiration for the individual exchange market. Our survey produced two important findings in this regard. First, the longer a consumer has been uninsured, the less likely he or she is to obtain coverage. For example, 65% of the respondents who had been uninsured for one year or less said they had shopped for a plan in 2017. In contrast, only 37% of those who had been uninsured for three years or more reported having done the same. Second, getting a significant number of uninsured individuals to purchase insurance appears to be possible. However, a marked change in incentives\u0026mdash;specifically, the addition of downside risk for not having coverage\u0026mdash;may be required.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe individual mandate penalty, which was eliminated in the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017, is one type of downside risk, but other options have been considered. In our survey, we explored customer reactions to several of these options (in all cases, we asked respondents to assume that the individual mandate penalty had been removed). Two types of downside risk produced significant increases in the percentage of uninsured individuals who said they would purchase insurance (Exhibit 4):[[footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 4]]\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWaiting period and surcharge.\u003c/strong\u003e The first scenario focused on what uninsured respondents would do if not having insurance for 63 or more days would result in them having to wait until the next calendar year to regain coverage and then having to pay a 30% surcharge every month of the first year for the new plan.[[footnote 8]] Sixty-seven percent of the uninsured said that they would enroll in a plan in this scenario. This result is consistent with effects we have observed in the Medicare Part D market, where consumers\u0026rsquo; premiums can increase based on how long they have gone without \u0026ldquo;creditable\u0026rdquo; prescription drug coverage.[[footnote 9]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCoverage denial or premium increases.\u003c/strong\u003e The second scenario focused on what uninsured respondents would do if a coverage gap of 63 days or more gave health insurers the right to deny them coverage if they developed a new medical condition or take that condition into account when pricing the plan.[[footnote 10]] In this scenario, 71% of the uninsured said they would obtain coverage. This result is consistent with what we have observed in the disability and life insurance markets, where purchasers have a financial incentive to sign up for coverage before they develop an adverse condition.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn contrast, there is some evidence that, in isolation, penalties are not understood by respondents or causing them to change their behavior. For example, about two-thirds of the uninsured respondents indicated that they were not aware of the individual mandate penalty. Among the uninsured who were aware of it, less than half said they had paid a penalty for not having insurance in 2016.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eMore details about the uninsured survey respondents can be found in the sidebar below.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eLimited perception of premium increases\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough gross premiums in the individual exchange market rose by an average of 25% in 2017,[[footnote 11]] our survey indicates that most purchasers were insulated from the increasing costs or were unaware of the increase in premiums they experienced.[[footnote 12]] Among the respondents who had health insurance coverage, 66% reported that their premiums had decreased, stayed the same, or increased by no more than 10% from 2016 to 2017. These results can likely be attributed, in part, to the subsidies many purchasers received.[[footnote 13]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eNevertheless, many of the purchasers indicated that they were facing challenges because of high costs. For example, 17% of the insured respondents reported that they had stopped paying their premiums in 2017\u0026mdash;yet 84% of this group repurchased an exchange plan in 2017 (Exhibit 5). In fact, 29% of these respondents repurchased the same plan they had stopped paying for in 2016. These findings are consistent with the results of a previous surveys, which found that one in five ACA-insured respondents had stopped paying their premiums in 2015\u0026mdash;87% of whom then repurchased an exchange plan in 2016.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 5]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eSimilarly, about 21% of the 2017 respondents reported having overdue medical bills. The median amount owed was roughly $1,400. And, 34% of the respondents said they had tried to negotiate down a medical bill with a hospital or doctor.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eConsumer trade-offs to reduce costs\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n[[sidebar sidebar]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eOur survey results show that many consumers would like to better manage their healthcare costs, including premiums and out-of-pocket payments, and are willing to take actions to do so. For example, 35% of the uninsured respondents said that, to reduce their costs, they had avoided visiting a doctor for a minor illness in the past 12 months. Similarly, 20% of the uninsured respondents reported having asked for generic alternatives when prescribed medication, and 13% had postponed elective treatments. Individually insured patients said they would take similar actions in the future if they did not have coverage.[[footnote 14]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition, most respondents said they were willing to make changes to their plans to reduce costs. When the respondents were asked to trade off between benefits and premium, the benefits chosen for removal most often were maternity/newborn care, mental health coverage, and preferred branded drugs. (Interestingly, men and women were equally likely to say they would forfeit maternity/newborn care, but few young respondents of either sex were willing to make this trade-off.[[footnote 15]]) The top three benefits respondents said they wanted to keep were hospitalization, emergency room services, and urgent care. Thus, it appears that there is an opportunity to increase consumer engagement through product design.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eHealth savings accounts (HSAs) are another option consumers could potentially use to help lower their out-of-pocket medical expenses (e.g., deductibles, coinsurance, co-payments). In our survey, however, 79% of the respondents said they had never had an HSA, and roughly half the respondents did not know which healthcare expenses could be paid for with an HSA. Furthermore, when low-income respondents were asked what they would do if, instead of cost-sharing reductions, they received an equivalent amount as an HSA deposit, one in five said they would drop their existing insurance coverage (Exhibit 6).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 6]]\n\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eOur survey findings provide strong indications that consumer understanding and behavior in the individual exchange market is stabilizing. Nevertheless, stakeholders across the healthcare industry have opportunities to encourage the uninsured to purchase coverage and to empower consumers to make the trade-offs that could potentially help them address concerns about rising healthcare costs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[sidebar appendix]]\n\n[[disruptorsignup full-width]]"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2018-07-28T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThis survey included both individually insured and uninsured respondents to understand the attitudes and purchasing behaviors of consumers who are eligible for coverage in the individual exchange market. Those enrolled in employer-sponsored insurance, Medicare, or Medicaid, as well as those uninsured who are Medicaid-eligible, were excluded from the survey population. See additional details on the survey design and respondents in the appendix.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMcKinsey is a non-partisan firm and has a long-standing policy of neither commenting on nor advocating for specific government policies. We do not provide policy advice, and the findings in this paper should not be taken as such.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThis finding is consistent with reports that despite significant changes to the 2018 OEP, 11.8 million people enrolled for coverage\u0026mdash;only a 3.7% drop from last year\u0026rsquo;s total enrollment. (National Academy for State Health Policy. Individual market enrollment remains stable in the face of national uncertainty. February 8, 2018.)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIn the absence of the individual mandate penalty, additional downside risk mechanisms could include surcharges (when purchasing coverage) for not having been insured for a period of time or the possibility of being denied future coverage.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe McKinsey Center for U.S. Health System Reform has calculated that the changes to net premium varied in 2017 from a decrease of as much as 13% to an increase of as much as 21%, depending on income level and resulting subsidy eligibility.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eWhile some of those who stopped paying premiums may have gained other forms of coverage, the majority remained in the individual exchanged market, as we discuss later in the article.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe approaches to downside risk tested in the survey were based on various Republican and Democratic proposals from early 2017; additional details are included in the appendix.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThis approach was based on a proposal that had been included in the American Health Care Act of 2017 (H.R. 1628). That Act was passed by the House of Representatives but not by the Senate.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMedicare Part D enrollees that have not had \u0026ldquo;creditable prescription drug coverage\u0026rdquo; for a continuous period of 63 days or more will pay a penalty amount in addition to base-level premiums that equals 1% of the national base beneficiary premium.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThis scenario was based on actions permissible to payers prior to passage of the Affordable Care Act.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eASPE Research Brief. Health plan choice and premiums in the 2018 federal health insurance exchange. October 30, 2017.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMcKinsey Center for U.S. Health System Reform. Insights into the 2018 individual exchange market. November 2017.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe McKinsey Center for U.S. Health System Reform has calculated that the changes to net premium varied in 2017 from a decrease of as much as 13% to an increase of as much as 21%, depending on income level and resulting subsidy eligibility.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eWhen the individually insured respondents were asked about the actions they would take to reduce medical costs if they did not have insurance, 42% said they would avoid visiting a doctor for a minor illness, 42% said they would ask for generic alternatives when prescribed medication, and 25% said they would postpone elective treatments.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e58% of men and 58% women said that they would be willing to remove this benefit to reduce premiums.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"contributoryPractice":{"targetItems":[{"displayName":"Healthcare"}]},"aboutTheAuthors":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/jenny-cordina\"\u003eJenny Cordina\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Detroit office. \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/erica-coe\"\u003eErica Coe\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner in the Atlanta office. \u003cstrong\u003eKyle Weber\u003c/strong\u003e is an associate partner in the Chicago office. \u003cstrong\u003eElizabeth P. current on your favorite topics"}}}]},"articlesidebar":{"results":[{"mediaID":{"value":"appendix"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003ch3\u003eMcKinsey ACA market survey\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThrough the McKinsey Center for U.S. Health System Reform, we regularly survey a national sample of QHP-eligible uninsured and individually insured consumers (excluding those eligible for Medicaid and Medicare). This research is independently funded by McKinsey \u0026amp; Company without contribution from any third party. The objective is to understand the actions, shopping, and purchasing behavior of consumers who are eligible to purchase individual coverage on the individual market exchanges or elsewhere. These surveys therefore provide snapshots of enrollment over time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eTo date, we have completed nine rounds of surveys:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003eNovember 25 to December 6, 2013: sample size of 1,846\u003c/li\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003eDecember 16 to December 20, 2013: sample size of 1,677\u003c/li\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003eJanuary 6 to January 10, 2014: sample size of 1,040\u003c/li\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003eFebruary 4 to February 13, 2014: sample size of 2,096\u003c/li\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003eApril 7 to April 16, 2014: sample size of 2,874\u003c/li\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003eNovember 6 to November 10, 2014: sample size of 2,000\u003c/li\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003eFebruary 21 to February 24, 2015: sample size of 3,007\u003c/li\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003eFebruary 2 to February 18, 2016: sample size of 2,763\u003c/li\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003eSeptember 21 to October 18, 2017: sample size 2,993\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eEach survey was designed and analyzed by McKinsey teams. Each survey was administered online in English by a third-party vendor. For the 2017 survey, we used the following characteristics to focus on the consumer segments eligible to purchase individual coverage on the exchanges or elsewhere:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003eAges 18 to 64\u003c/li\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003eIncome above 100% federal poverty level (FPL) in Medicaid non-expansion states and above 138% FPL in Medicaid expansion states\u003c/li\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003eInclusive of both insured and uninsured individuals for 2017, regardless of coverage in 2016\u003c/li\u003e\n\t\u003cli\u003ePrimary decision-maker, equally involved in making decisions, or contributes to health insurance decisions for their household\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eA portion of the content for this year\u0026rsquo;s survey, including various proposals that were tested, was intended to be generally consistent with formal and informal proposals from Democratic and Republican leadership that had emerged in the first half of 2017.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Appendix"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"sidebar"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eEncouraging more uninsured individuals to obtain health insurance coverage is an important goal.
